facts.text: Reference under Section 57 of the Indian Stamp Act, 1899 by Board of Revenue to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment of the High Court of Allahabad in a reference under S. 57 of the Indian Stamp Act, 1899.

facts.text: Respondent is one of the executants of the deed dated December 15, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are as follows. The respondent is one of the executants of the deed dated December 15, 1952.

facts.text: Executants (vendors) were lessees of two plots of land.

anchor.surface_text: The executants, hereinafter referred to as the vendors, were lessees of two plots of land and on these plots

facts.text: Vendors constructed an oil mill known as Sri Govind Oil Mills, an Ice and Cold Storage Factory, and buildings.

anchor.surface_text: they had companystructed an oil mill, known as Sri Govind Oil Mills, an Ice and Cold Storage Factory, and buildings

facts.text: Ice and Cold Storage factory run by vendors in partnership with Shyam Sunder Gupta and Satya Prakash Gupta.

anchor.surface_text: in which the factories stood. The Ice and Cold Storage factory was being run by the vendors in partnership with

facts.text: Vendors equitably mortgaged properties with Chartered Bank of India, sum of Rs. 10,00,000 due to the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: The vendors had equitably mortgaged these properties with the Chartered Bank of India, and a sum of Rs. 10,00,000

facts.text: Vendors entered into contract with Messrs Oil Corporation of India Ltd. (vendees) for sale of lands, buildings, plants, machinery, stores and goodwill for Rs. 5,55,000.

anchor.surface_text: In order to pay off the debt, the vendors entered into a companytract with Messrs Oil Corporation of India Ltd., hereinafter

facts.text: Sale consideration breakdown: Rs. 1,12,000 for plant and machinery and goodwill of Ice and Cold Storage Factory, Rs. 3,00,000 for machinery of Sri Govind Oil Mills, Rs. 25,000 for stores, Rs. 18,000 for goodwill, Rs. 1,00,000 for buildings and lessee right.

anchor.surface_text: for the sale of the lands, buildings, plants, machinery and stores and goodwill of the Govind Oil Mills and Ice Cold Storage Factory for a sum of Rs. 5,55,000, made up as follows

facts.text: Out of Rs. 5,55,000, Rs. 66,000 payable to Shyam Sunder Gupta and Satya Prakash Gupta for their share.

anchor.surface_text: Out of this Rs. 66,000 was payable to Messrs Shyam Sunder Gupta and Satya Parkash Gupta in respect of their share

facts.text: Chartered Bank agreed to release properties if Rs. 5,00,000 paid to it.

anchor.surface_text: The Chartered Bank agreed to release from its charge the properties to be companyveyed to the vendees provided

facts.text: Vendees agreed to pay Rs. 4,89,000 to Bank, vendors Rs. 11,000.

anchor.surface_text: a sum of Rs. 5,00,000 was paid to it. The vendees agreed to pay the said Bank a sum of Rs. 4,89,000, while the vendors

facts.text: Vendors handed over possession of plant and machinery to vendees.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this agreement, the vendors handed over the possession of plant and machinery of the two factories

facts.text: Vendees paid Rs. 3,89,000 to Bank before December 15, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: to the vendees, who paid before December 15, 1952, Rs. 3,89,000 to the said Bank.

facts.text: Sale-deed executed on December 15, 1952 in respect of buildings and lessee rights.

anchor.surface_text: On December 15, 1952, the sale-deed in respect of the buildings and the lessee rights was executed.

facts.text: Clause 2 of deed: vendees declare properties free from encumbrances except charge to Chartered Bank, to be paid off.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 2 of the deed provided that the vendees hereby declare that the properties hereby companyveyed are free from all encumbrances except the charge

facts.text: High Court held document is sale deed for consideration of Rs. 1,00,000 only, stamp duty on that amount.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court gave the following answer to the first three questions The document in question is a sale deed for a companysideration of Rs. 1,00,000 only

facts.text: Appellant (Board of Revenue) challenges High Court's answer to first three questions.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the Board of Revenue, challenges the answer given by the High Court to the said three questions.

facts.text: On December 15, 1952, Rs. 3,89,000 already paid by vendees to Bank.

anchor.surface_text: On December 15, 1952, the date when the deed was executed, Rs. 3,89,000 had already been paid by the vendees

facts.text: Payment of Rs. 3,89,000 to Bank left outstanding Rs. 1,11,000 as mortgage money.

anchor.surface_text: The payment of Rs. 3,89,000 to the Bank left outstanding Rs. 1,11,000 as mortgage money.

facts.text: Rs. 1,00,000 expressed as consideration for conveyance of immovable property.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 1,00,000 is expressed to be the companysideration for the companyveyance of the immovable property

facts.text: High Court held Rs. 11,000 not to be included as vendors liable, property sold free from charge.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that till the date of sale the sum of 1 1,000 had number been paid and there was a charge on the property in respect of that amount.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that stamp duty calculated on Rs. 1,00,000.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we agree with the High Court that the stamp duty is to be calculated only on the sum of Rs. 1,00,000.

facts.text: Board of Revenue referred questions to High Court on stamp duty.

anchor.surface_text: The Board of Revenue referred the following questions to the High Court Whether the document is a sale-deed for a companysideration

facts.text: Fourth question on additional stamp duty under section 107 of Kanpur Development Act, 1945 not subject of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention that the answer to the fourth question is number the subject matter of appeal before us.

facts.text: Vendees paid Rs. 4,55,000 for items other than immovable property.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear from the terms of the deed that Rs. 4,55,000 was to be paid for items other than the immovable property

anchor.surface_text: Explanation.-In the case of a sale of property subject to a mortgage or other incumbrance, any unpaid mortgage money or money charged, together with the interest (if any) due on the same, shall be deemed to be part of the consideration for the sale

concepts.interpretation: Applies only when property is sold 'subject to' the mortgage, meaning purchaser takes subject to it; here, property sold free from charge except to be paid off, vendors liable for Rs.11,000.

issues.text: Whether the document is a sale-deed for a consideration of Rs. 1,00,000 as contended by the executants.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the document is a sale-deed for a consideration of Rs. 1,00,000 as contended by the executants.

issues.text: Whether in view of the provisions of Section 24 of the Stamp Act, the sale consideration shall be deemed to be Rs. 5,55,000 and duty liable to be paid thereon as held by the Board.

anchor.surface_text: Whether in view of the provisions of Section 24 of the Stamp Act, the sale consideration shall be deemed to be Rs. 5,55,000

issues.text: What is the underlying object of the section?

anchor.surface_text: The first question which we may pose is What is the underlying object of the section ? Illustration 2 to the section reads A sells a property to B for Rs. 500 which is subject to a mortgage to C for Rs. 1,000 and unpaid interest Rs. 200. Stamp-duty is payable on Rs. 1,700.

issues.text: What does the phrase sale of property subject to a mortgage mean?

anchor.surface_text: The next point that needs determination is What does the phrase sale of property subject to a mortgage mean ? Does this phrase mean that whenever mortgaged property is sold the explanation applies or does it imply that if mortgaged property is sold subject to the mortgage then and then only the explanation applies

issues.text: Whether Rs. 3,89,000 should be included in the consideration for the purpose of calculating ad valorem duty?

anchor.surface_text: On December 15, 1952, the date when the deed was executed, Rs. 3,89,000 had already been paid by the vendees to the Bank. Mr. Aggarwala contends that this amount should be included because it was consideration moving from the vendees.

issues.text: Whether the sum of Rs. 11,000 should be taken into consideration for the purpose of levying stamp duty.

arguments.claim: The document in question is a sale deed for a consideration of Rs. 1,00,000 only and the stamp duty payable in respect of it was to be calculated on the amount and not on any higher amount.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court gave the following answer to the first three questions The document in question is a sale deed for a companysideration of Rs. 1,00,000 only

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed after detailed analysis that only Rs. 1,00,000 is consideration for immovable property under Art. 23; payments for movables and not subject to mortgage excluded under s. 24.

arguments.claim: On a true interpretation of s. 24 of the Indian Stamp Act, 1899, the consideration for the purpose of calculating ad valorem duty is either Rs. 10,00,000, or Rs. 5,55,000 or at least Rs. 1,11,000.

arguments.court_reasoning: S. 24 deems debt part of consideration only if transfer subject to it or sale subject to mortgage; here property conveyed free except charge to be paid off, vendors liable for Rs. 11,000.

arguments.claim: The underlying object of s. 24 is to deem unpaid mortgage money as part of consideration when property is sold subject to mortgage to prevent undervaluation and tax evasion, as per Illustration 2.

anchor.surface_text: The first question which we may pose is What is the underlying object of the section ? Illustration 2 to the section reads A sells a property to B for Rs. 500 which is subject to a mortgage to C for Rs. 1,000

arguments.claim: The phrase 'sale of property subject to a mortgage' in Explanation to s. 24 means the sale is subject to the mortgage (qualifies 'sale'), not merely that the property is mortgaged; supported by Calcutta HC in Janardhana Rao and Bombay HC in Waman Martand.

anchor.surface_text: The next point that needs determination is What does the phrase sale of property subject to a mortgage mean ? Does this phrase mean that whenever mortgaged property is sold the explanation applies

arguments.claim: Stamp Act being a taxing statute must be construed strictly, and if two meanings are equally possible, the meaning in favour of the subject must be preferred.

anchor.surface_text: We need hardly say that the Stamp Act is a taxing statute and must be construed strictly, and if two meanings are equally possible, the meaning

arguments.claim: Rs. 3,89,000 paid by vendees to Bank before deed should be included in consideration as it was consideration moving from vendees and stamp duty cannot be avoided by paying before execution of conveyance.

anchor.surface_text: On December 15, 1952, the date when the deed was executed, Rs. 3,89,000 had already been paid by the vendees Mr. Aggarwala contends that this amount should be included

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 8 Ct. of Sess. cases, 4th S. 389 Rs. 1,700 which is the companysideration expressed in terms of Art. 23, and Rs. 1,200 deemed to be companysideration

arguments.court_reasoning: Rs. 3,89,000 part of Rs. 4,55,000 paid for movables (machinery, stores, goodwill), not for immovable property conveyed; falls outside Art. 23 and s. 24.

arguments.claim: Rs. 11,000 not included as vendors took liability to pay it, property sold free from charge, vendees not liable, so not sold subject to charge; Explanation to s. 24 inapplicable; part of price for other items.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that till the date of sale the sum of 1 1,000 had not been paid and there was a charge on the property in respect of that amount.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tances the property cannot be said to have been sold subject to the charge of Rs. 1 1,000, and if it was number being sold subject to that charge, the

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellant did not seriously controvert; property not subject to charge of Rs. 11,000 as vendors liable and deed states free except charge to be paid off.

arguments.claim: Explanation to s. 24 deems only unpaid mortgage money as part of consideration at time of conveyance; if paid before by vendee as part of consideration for property, included under Art. 23 if recited, not under Explanation.

anchor.surface_text: Before we consider the facts of this case, we may mention that it is plain from the explanation that it is only the unpaid mortgage money that is deemed to be part of the consideration.

holdings.text: the phrase 'sale of property subject to a mortgage' means mortgaged property sold subject to the mortgage, such that the explanation to Section 24 applies only then

anchor.surface_text: The next point that needs determination is What does the phrase sale of property subject to a mortgage mean ? Does this phrase mean that whenever mortgaged property is sold the explanation applies or does it imply that if mortgaged property is sold subject to the mortgage then and then only the explanation applies In our view, the correct meaning is the latter meaning. Let us see what would be the position if A, instead of selling property as in illustration 2, adopts the following mode of selling. A sells property to B for Rs. 1,700, which is subject to mortgage to C for Rs. 1,000 and unpaid interest Rs. 200. A agrees that Rs. 1,200 be paid to C and Rs. 500 to him. If the first meaning is adopted, the consideration on which the stamp duty would be leviable would be

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of phrase structure; hypothetical to show absurdity of alternative; follows Calcutta HC (Janardhana Rao) and Bombay HC (Waman Martand); strict construction of taxing statute favors subject.

holdings.text: The Stamp Act being a taxing statute must be construed strictly, and if two meanings are equally possible, the meaning in favour of the subject must be preferred

anchor.surface_text: We need hardly say that the Stamp Act is a taxing statute and must be construed strictly, and if two meanings are equally possible, the meaning in favour of the subject must be given effect to.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard canon for taxing statutes applied to resolve ambiguity in s.24 Explanation.

holdings.text: only the unpaid mortgage money that is deemed to be part of the consideration under the Explanation to s.24

anchor.surface_text: Before we consider the facts of this case, we may mention that it is plain from the explanation that it is only the unpaid mortgage money that is deemed to be part of the consideration. If the mortgage money has been paid off by the date of the conveyance the explanation does not require it to be added to the consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual reading of Explanation; distinguishes from payments made before conveyance which would be recited under Art.23 if for the property.

holdings.text: Rs. 3,89,000 paid to Bank prior to deed not part of consideration for stamp duty as it relates to movable property (machinery etc.), not the immovable property conveyed

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear from the terms of the deed that Rs. 4,55,000 was to be paid for items other than the immovable property conveyed by the said deed, and the sum of Rs. 3,89,000 had nothing to do with the immovable property. The payment of Rs. 3,89,000 to the Bank left outstanding Rs. 1,11,000 as mortgage money. Rs. 1,00,000 is expressed to be the consideration for the conveyance of the immovable property

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deed terms allocate Rs.4,55,000 to movables outside Art.23 scope; payment to Bank part of that; only Rs.1,00,000 for immovable under Art.23.

holdings.text: Rs. 11,000 remaining mortgage money not included in consideration as vendors liable to pay it, property sold free from that charge, not 'subject to' mortgage for Explanation to s.24

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Aggarwala has not seriously controverted the finding of the High Court on this point. Accordingly, we hold that this sum of Rs. 11,000 cannot be included for the purpose of levying stamp duty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts High Court finding (not controverted); deed clause declares property free except charge to be paid off; vendors undertook liability; not sold 'subject to' charge.

holdings.text: stamp duty payable only on Rs. 1,00,000, the expressed consideration for the immovable property conveyed

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we agree with the High Court that the stamp duty is to be calculated only on the sum of Rs. 1,00,000.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Art.23 to expressed Rs.1L for buildings/lessee rights; exclusions under s.24 analysis for mortgage portions; agrees with High Court answers to first three questions.

The holding that stamp duty is payable only on the expressed consideration of Rs. 1,00,000 for the immovable property is grounded in the definition of 'sale' under Section 2(10), which links sale to consideration.
Section 2(10) defines 'sale' as relevant to determining if the document qualifies as a sale-deed for the contended consideration of Rs. 1,00,000.

anchor.surface_text: The next point that needs determination is What does the phrase sale of property subject to a mortgage mean ? Does this phrase mean that whenever mortgaged property is sold the explanation applies or does it imply that if mortgaged property is sold subject to the mortgage then and then only the explanation applies In our view, the correct meaning is the latter meaning. Let us see what would be the position if A, instead of selling property as in illustration 2, adopts the following mode of selling. A sells property to B for Rs. 1,700, which is subject to mortgage to C for Rs. 1,000 and unpaid interest Rs. 200. A agrees that Rs. 1,200 be paid to C and Rs. 500 to him. If the first meaning is adopted, the consideration on which the stamp duty would be leviable would be

Accordingly, we hold that this sum of Rs. 1 1,000 cannot be included for the purpose of levying stamp duty. In the result, we agree with the High Court that the stamp duty is to be calculated only on the sum of Rs. 1,00,000.
